tool.name: GEMINI @BINARY@
tool.description: Loading a VCF file into GEMINI
tool.command:
ln -s "${ infile }" input.vcf && bgzip -c input.vcf > input.vcf.gz && tabix -p vcf input.vcf.gz &&
gemini #if $annotation_databases: --annotation-dir "${annotation_databases.fields.path}" #end if @BINARY@ -v input.vcf.gz #if str( $annotation_type ) != "None": -t "$annotation_type" #end if
#if $ped: -p $ped #end if
$skip_gerp_bp $skip_cadd $skip_gene_tables $no_load_genotypes $no_genotypes $passonly $infostring --cores \${GALAXY_SLOTS:-4}
"${ outfile }"

param.name: infile
param.label: VCF file to be loaded in the GEMINI database
param.help: Only build 37 (aka hg19) of the human genome is supported.

param.name: annotation_type
param.label: The annotations to be used with the input vcf

param.name: ped
param.label: Sample information file in PED+ format

param.name: skip_gerp_bp
param.label: Do not load GERP scores at base pair resolution

param.name: no_load_genotypes
param.label: Genotypes exist in the file, but should not be stored

param.name: no_genotypes
param.label: There are no genotypes in the file

param.name: passonly
param.label: Keep only variants that pass all filters

param.name: infostring
param.label: Load INFO string from VCF file

tool.help:
**What it does**
Before we can use GEMINI to explore genetic variation, we must first load our VCF file into the GEMINI database framework. We expect you to have first annotated the functional consequence of each variant in your VCF using either VEP or snpEff.
